<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18876>

            Bug ID: 18876
           Summary: Install packages on non-appendable file systems (e.g.
                    databricks volumes)
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.5.x
          Hardware: All
                OS: Linux
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Installation
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:sergioller@gmail.com|sergioller@gmail.com>

Created attachment 3470
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3470&action=edit>
Patch with docs

I am working at a company, and we use R with databricks. We want to install
some packages on a distributed filesystem that is not fully POSIX compliant, as
it does not support opening files in append mode. In C terms, `open(filename,
"a")` gives an error. I guess other distributed file systems beyond the ones in
databricks may have issues with append mode as well.

R source package installation requires opening files in append mode, so the
installation of such packages fails. Our current workaround is to install all
packages on a local folder, and then copy/move the folder to the distributed
file system.

The submitted patch allows sysadmins to define the R_LOCKDIR_PREFIX environment
variable, so the 00LOCK directory where the package is temporarily installed by
install packages can be set to be created in a different file system.

This allows source package installations to succeed in those systems.

The main caveat of this patch, as pointed by Tomas Kalibera on
<https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-devel/2025-March/083925.html> is that the final
copy from the lockdir to the final destination is not atomic if the LOCK
directory is on a different file system. This is an issue because in case of
error during the copy, the resulting library directory can be left in a
corrupted state.

I have stated this caveat explicitly in the R Installation and admin manual,
where the environment variable is documented.

In my opinion the robust approach would require improving the filesystem
driver, so the filesystem would offer "append mode support" and "atomic
directory operations" (or in general POSIX compliance).

Still, I believe that the patch has value, since it enables source package
installation in those file systems, even if it is with limited error recovery
capabilities.

--- Comment #3 from Mikael Jagan (<mailto:jaganmn@mcmaster.ca|jaganmn@mcmaster.ca>) ---
[TLDR: My feeling is that this PR can be closed with a very small patch to
`UseMethod.Rd`, provided below.]

I found my way here from R-devel:
<https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-devel/2025-March/083913.html>

From my point of view, there *are* uses for the current behaviour of
`NextMethod` which allows its "formal" argument `...` to be matched by unnamed
"actual" arguments.  Consider a class `A` defined informally as a numeric
vector holding a second numeric vector as an attribute named `extra`.  The
author of the class decides that

```
Summary(x, ..., na.rm = y)
```

should behave as

```
Summary(as.numeric(x), ..., na.rm = y, attr(x, "extra"))
```

for `x` inheriting from `A`.  So they do:

```
> Summary.A <- function(x, ..., na.rm = FALSE) NextMethod(, , attr(x, "extra"))
> x <- structure(c(2, 2), extra = 4, class = "A")
> prod(x)
[1] 16
```

And that seems reasonable enough to me.  I'd not want to prevent or discourage
people from doing such things.

Are these "misusers" of `NextMethod` reading the *official* documentation?  I
tend to agree with Simon's position that it is already documented how arguments
matching `...` are handled:
<https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-devel/2012-October/065017.html>

`RShowDoc("R-lang")`:

> Values in the `...` argument are used to modify the arguments of the next method.

`help("NextMethod")`:

> Normally `NextMethod` is used with only one argument, `generic`, but if further arguments are supplied these modify the call to the next method.
>
> ...
>
> Any named arguments matched to `...` are handled specially: they either replace existing arguments of the same name or are appended to the argument list.

So maybe just a very small patch to `UseMethod.Rd` to say explicitly what
happens to *unnamed* arguments matched to `...`?

```
Index: src/library/base/man/UseMethod.Rd
===================================================================
--- src/library/base/man/UseMethod.Rd   (revision 88064)
+++ src/library/base/man/UseMethod.Rd   (working copy)
@@ -109,7 +109,8 @@
   method.  If no new arguments are supplied, the arguments will be the
   same in number, order and name as those to the current method but
   their values will be promises to evaluate their name in the current
-  method and environment.  Any named arguments matched to \code{\dots}
+  method and environment.  Unnamed arguments matched to \code{\dots} are
+  appended to the argument list.  Named arguments matched to \code{\dots}
   are handled specially: they either replace existing arguments of the
   same name or are appended to the argument list.  They are passed on as
   the promise that was supplied as an argument to the current
```
